CommentsTitle: Crumb Tray is Not Removable. That's a Deal-Breaker.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 10, 2020
CommentsContent: I can't stand having old food sitting at the bottom of my toaster oven. My old Black and Decker toaster oven had a removable crumb tray. Just slide it out, empty it in the trashcan and/or scrub in the sink, then (when dry), slide back in. I don't know how a modern toaster oven can be designed without this feature/convenience, but this Mueller oven is. It is so frustrating to have this simple feature be over-looked, that I had to return these (I bought 2).My beef with the crumb tray is that it is not removable. From the owners manual:"How to Clean the Crumb Tray. 1) Turn the oven on it's back. 2) Push the crumb tray knob down and then pull it. 3) clean the crumb tray. 4) After cleaning, return the Crumb Tray in it's place."The first step alone (turn it on it's back!) just makes me wonder why this was designed this way as that makes cleaning it so inconvenient.And we all know that our kids will make a pizza or burrito in the oven from time to time which means cheese and other ingredients that are going to leak and burn onto the crumb tray. Imagine not being able to easily clean that up.It's hard to speak to the other features because for me the crumb tray issue is so big, but in fairness, the unit looks nice. Wife made a small pizza in it and it cooked fast. Some toast or a bagel, however, was not evenly cooked (top or bottom cooked significantly more).It is very light weight, which makes it feel cheap. But I think most toaster ovens around this price point are probably light in weight.As others have mentioned, the controls are quite stiff so someone with aching joints might have a problem operating it. Maybe they will soften up with use but initially they are pretty hard to turn.I saw the dimensions in some other reviews and noticed some variance, so here's what I get with my trusty tape measure. The dimensions are (roughly) 14 3/4" W x 9" H x 9"D (not including the handle on front). It is a little smaller than what we thought it would be.One final note: Something that piqued my interest was that this company is Mueller of Austria. They go out of their way to include "of Austria" in the logo and my impression was that this unit may be manufactured in Austria and to me, for whatever reason, that inferred quality and precision. I should have known better, but upon checking the box, and it was no surprise, but it is manufactured in China. And by the way, as I guess nowadays people are paying more attention to country of origin, they state "Made in PRC" (Peoples Republic of China), I guess to try to trick anyone that doesn't know what "PRC" stands for and might be averse to buying product made in China. I'm not accusing Mueller of false advertising, but it's just a tad bit shady, and I don't like that.I think if a few improvements are made, this oven could move up a notch or two, but for now they are going back and I will continue shopping.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 6, 2019
CommentsContent: So far I've used this oven only for baking potatoes and toasting bread and bagels. The toasting function works well, turning out evenly browned bread, once you learn how to set the timing and position the bread in the oven. (It seems there are only two positions for the rack, but this becomes four if you turn the rack upside down.) This involves turning the heat control to the maximum setting, deciding whether you want to brown both sides or only the top (by activating both elements or only the top one). Adjusting the timer for toasting is a skill acquired through practice, as the gradations are narrow, requiring good eyesight and some practice. (Be prepared to scrape some pieces of over-toasted bread at the sink until you learn.) By the way, the timer runs only 30 minutes, so the "stay on" setting is well conceived and essential for foods requiring long cook times. But you'll need a supplemental timer; I use the timer on my microwave oven.The temperature control on the unit I have is ridiculously out of whack. After burning the skin on a couple of russet potatoes to a crisp, I used an oven thermometer to learn the truth. It turned out that on my machine the setting for 400 degrees F. is 290 degrees! Now that I know this, I can bake russet potatoes perfectly. But by any standards this must be considered a major defect. On the plus side, the oven is small, so its 1100 watt power is entirely adequate.This machine, compared with other toaster ovens I've owned, has the footprint of a postage stamp. The tiny amount of space it takes up on the countertop is one of its most attractive features. Additionally, the machine, by my taste, has a very attractive design, and it is made of sturdy materials, given its modest price. It seems well constructed as well.I've grown fond of the little bugger, my affection enhanced by the challenge of learning to use it, which definitely takes some experimentation and a touch of ingenuity. But if you're short on time and mechanically deficient, forget this demanding little beauty.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 4, 2020
CommentsContent: Wow. Out of the box, this oven met my expectations which are high. We've had the Hamilton Beach 2 in 1 for over 15 years and although still working, it's old and a little under-powered. We've since grown to a family of four so toasting bread requires a tad more space and yet, we don't want to take up too much countertop space. This is Perfect sized for our needs. The stainless steel is beautiful and matches our kitchen. The dial from ez bottom rack/bake, top rack/broil & both racks/toast is simple. There's a standard temp setting. And the timer works well, with a mechanical 'ding'. I just followed the directions to clean the inside and 'toast/oven clean' for 15 minutes so indeed the place stunk up (this is a must!!). However, I'm no longer concerned with factory chemicals and can't wait to use it tomorrow. At $60, this seems costly compared to our old 2 in1 at $40 but this thing is gorgeous so we can't wait to test out all the functions. Will edit further as needed.*edit* 17 days later and we've been using this daily. Kids are home and love toasted bread or bagels. The 3-way toast-bake-broil settings work perfectly. Takes a bit to get used to calibrating settings - ex. 450* vs. 400* for the 'toast', middle vs bottom rack placement, & timer (<5 min low-med-high toast functions). That said, we absolutely LOVE this. In fact, my wife recently claimed this as a top electronics purchase for 2020, if not the decade. We're already reheated meats (makes a good 'sear' on leftover roast pork) & chicken nuggets (amazing chicken breast from AmazonFresh) & can't wait to try other 'heavier' things (ex. tater tots although we defaulted to the oven given size). Of note, we tried bacon (4 slices per, twice) and this works perfect. Less mess to clean up or worry about vs. the full-sized oven. I may consider cooking steak, pork chops, or chicken but for now, so far so good. My only complaint, & it's a tiny one is the timer dial requires a '90*' turn to activate well (mechanical spring action), which is is at the 10 min. mark so anything less, you need to 'dial' counterclockwise/back. When cooking, hands are often slipper so not easy to do. The 'notch' marker helps the grip but could be 'deeper' or simply, I just grab a towel or potwarmer. Not a deal-breaker but very noticeable, esp. when I have to 'retoast' my bread for just that extra 10-30 secs. This happens a lot with picky kids where there's a fine balance between 'burnt' & goldilocks just right. All in all, still a 5 star product!! I really can't wait to use it more to avoid having to using my regular oven (a convection one too!), which tends to draw too much heat and trigger my smoke detector (why are they in the kitchen again?!). I ordered separate trays (ex. 7" round pizza pans) and can't wait to make pizza with the kids. Inside fits 10" wide x 9" deep (the included multi-purpose pan is 10" wide x 8" deep.. not sure why the 0.5" gap on each end but perhaps to allow front-back circulation).
